title: Leeds woman helps homeless with her own money - BBC News
text:
Leeds woman helps homeless with her own money 7 February 2017 Close share panel Image caption Diane Dixon goes out into Leeds once a week to offer food to homeless people A woman is using her own money to cook food and hand it out to homeless people in Leeds. 
Diane Dixon, 49, of East End Park, buys food each week to cook and distribute to those living on the streets along with blankets and warm clothing. 
Mrs Dixon, who works part-time as a bookkeeper, has been making about 12 hot meals each week for about a year. 
Wayne Watson, originally from Holbeck, Leeds, said the work she does is a lifeline. 
"It just helps you," he said. 
"People will frown and say they shouldn't be doing it but I disagree. It provides a lot of support. These people coming round, it's only little but it helps a lot." Image caption The part-time bookeeper prepares about 12 hot meals each week 
Mrs Dixon sees herself as lucky enough to be able to afford to do something to help. 
"I'm in a fortunate position in that I can pay for it myself," she said. 
"I get looked after myself by my partner, he provides for me and I spend my wage on the homeless. 
"There are regular faces that we see, we see some new people now and again but most are regulars. 
"All of them say there is not enough help out for them. It's drink and drugs, marriage break-ups, anything can cause it." 
She said she usually cooks things like meatballs with pasta, pulled pork sandwiches and apple pie and custard and takes it round with a friend, Kai Kye, 30. 
Her partner, Richard Willis, 53, and their daughter Charlotte Dixon, 22, also help out on the rounds. One of the simplest ways is to alert a professional, to help rough sleepers access help and support Give food and time, not money Offer a gift like a hat, gloves, or clean dry socks For homeless people with dogs, offer them dog food 
The story comes as the homelessness charity Crisis warns homelessness is rising at an "appalling rate" . 
Figures from the Department for Communities and Local Government show more than half of councils in England recorded a rise in rough sleeping in 2016 compared with the year before. 
Matt Downie, director of policy and external affairs at Crisis, said: "Cold weather conditions can prove fatal for people sleeping on the streets. Tragically, the average age of death for a homeless person is just 47. 
"As temperatures drop, local authorities should be doing all they can to protect rough sleepers. This action could be a lifesaver for those with nowhere left to turn." Related Topics
